newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistani bourse seen weighing reforms cautiously.
newsitem.headline: Pakistani bourse seen weighing reforms cautiously.

text.p: The Pakistan stock market, though deperate for a good news, is likely to respond cautiously to what analysts termed a bold economic reform course laid out by the new finance chief of the interim government.

Shahid Javed Burki, the new adviser to caretaker Prime Minister Meraj Khalid and a World Bank vice president, in his first news conference set out a sweeping reform programme on Saturday to shore up the country's crumbling economic foundations and regain the favour of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank.

"The proposed changes are a combination of classic IMF and World Bank prescriptions as would be expected from Burki who is a serving vice-president at the World Bank," Abid Naqvi, head of research at Taurus Securities said.
Burki took a 90-day leave of absence from the World Bank after President Farooq Leghari, who sacked Benazir Bhutto's government on Tuesday, asked him to join the interim government.
Naqvi said the market, despite agreeing with the basic thrust of the programme, was cautious as key questions remain unanswered.
The Karachi Stock Exchange's 100-share index fell through the psychological barrier of 1,500 points on Sunday and fell 24.68 points, or 1.63 percent, to close at 1,492.19.
Naqvi said the market was not sure whether the interim government has enough time to generate sufficient momentum to implement the package through the existing inefficient bureaucratic machinery.
"Given its 90 day mandate, how will the interim government ensure continuity thereafter," he said.
Analysts say in many ways Burki's programme is reminiscent of that of Pakistan's last caretaker government in 1993 under Moeen Qureshi, whose reforms led to a short-lived agreement with the IMF.
"The previous such attempt under another World Bank official (Qureshi) failed on both counts," Naqvi said, noting the IMF agreement came to an abrupt end within 20 months.
Burki said on Saturday he would lay the groundwork for a cheaper, longer-term loan, or enhanced structural adjustment facility (ESAF), in the next few days.

Asked if his plans might unravel when a new political government is elected on February 3 -- just as Qureshi's did under the Bhutto government -- Burki said one important difference was that Leghari's term still has two years to run.
Analysts said, however, since the president will have to stand for re-election by a new parliament his ability to ensure continuity of the economic policies will be constrained.
Nadeem Naqvi, analyst at the International Asset Management Co Ltd, said foreign investors are also likely to wait and see how the political and the macro-economic situation changes.
"Investors are sceptical about how the new set up will improve economic indicators within three months, given the political scenario which is fluid at the moment," he said.
Nadeem Naqvi said foreign investors perceived that at least two quarters were needed to trigger an improvement in the economic indicators.

He said the market was likely to remain volatile as more news about the reform programme filtered through and predicted foreign investment inflows in the May-June 1997 quarter if the reforms remained on track.
"The only good thing is that maybe Pakistan has the last of its negative surprises when Moody's downgraded its rating," he said.
